events.title: United States Declaration of Independence adopted
events.description: The Continental Congress officially adopted the Declaration of Independence, declaring the thirteen American colonies independent from British rule.
events.significance: Marked the formal birth of the United States of America as an independent nation and a pivotal moment in world history promoting freedom and democracy.

events.title: President James A. Garfield dies
events.description: James A. Garfield, the 20th President of the United States, died from infections related to an assassination attempt that occurred earlier that year.
events.significance: His death led to increased efforts to reform civil service and highlighted the vulnerabilities of the presidency in the face of violence.

events.title: The Civil Rights Act signed into law
events.description: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, outlawing discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.
events.significance: A landmark law in the American civil rights movement that advanced equality and fought segregation and discrimination throughout the United States.

events.title: Hong Kong returned to China
events.description: The United Kingdom officially handed over sovereignty of Hong Kong to the People's Republic of China after 156 years of British rule.
events.significance: Marked the end of British colonial rule in Hong Kong and the beginning of the 'one country, two systems' principle under Chinese sovereignty.
